title: Do you need to have a degree in music to become a musician? - Quora

response.answer_text: Being a musician can mean many things. Obviously you don’t need any qualification to learn to play an instrument - many of the worlds best musicians don’t have one. If you want to play in a band then you just need to be able to do what’s required. If the band is recording then you may need to understand how studio work is done and may need to be able to read music scores. Many gigging musicians cannot read music and just learn to play everything by ear. If you want to be a session musician then it’s pretty much a requirement that you can sight-read music and perform very well. If you want to work in the music industry then depending on the role you may or may not need such a qualification. If you want to be a music teacher at a school or academy they may require it. So - the answer is - yes and no, depending on the circumstances. You definitely can have a great career as a musician without any qualifications if you have the ability to play well for the situations required.

I remember jazz great Rufus Reid saying that you can learn the music in the school or on the street. Doesn’t matter where. Each offers a community in which to grow. We need to be immersed in the music and the genres. I’m a fan of school as access to great teachers AND inspiring and talented students is possible. That’s what school is designed for. Music degrees are interesting. If you play really well, show up on time, work well with others, no one will care if you have a degree. But getting a degree is part of what teaches us to carry ourselves like professionals. People hire professionals who don't bring drama, are on time, have instruments in good condition, are prepared, etc. The college environment, depending upon how robust, prepares us well for this.

It depends on your goal. If you want to teach on a university level, then you actually need a doctorate if you want to even be considered for tenure track. As a performer, no, you really don’t. Either you can play or you can’t. Wes Montgomery is my go to example of someone who made it and yet could not read music at all. If you want to do serious studio work and musical pit work for others in a variety of styles, reading is essential and you have to be musically versatile. But that doesn’t mean you need a degree to do it.

“Are music diplomas actually necessary to pursue a music career?” In general? Not in the slightest. There are many tools an artist can use to create art. While a diploma can give you certain tools, those tools are by no means the only ones around. In fact, most of the music in the rock, folk, and hip-hop genres (as well as many others) have been made by people who learned what they know from playing and analyzing their favorite records and playing gigs. However, if you want a career as a music teacher, a composer, or a theatre or opera star? While perhaps not 100% necessary, it’s more likely than not that you’ll need at least a bachelor’s. Diplomas are pieces of paper that tell other prestigious institutions that you have acquired a certain set of skills. If you think those skills or that message to those institutions will work in your favor, then go for it! If not, then there are plenty of other ways to learn. Simple as that. Thanks for listening, and I hope this helps.

No. Most musicians don’t have degrees. A music degree is not required except for teaching positions. Some of the most-accomplished musicians and composers have no music degree. If you are interested in pursuing a career in music then do yourself a favor and have a backup career plan. The music business is not kind, even for the most-successful musicians, and having a good backup plan means you’ll have the means to forge a career even when times are tough… and for most musicians, believe me, there will be tough times.

It depends the genre of music. If it is a form of popular music, no. If it is classical music, most probably. However, information and skills in your chosen profession is rarely a detriment. There are several pop artists that are schooled in music, but that information is not generally made known.

Definitely not. But it helps a lot. Not only for developing your skills, but to connect with peers that share the same interests and maybe find people to challenge you or collaborate in projects. And lastly, if your music career doesn’t work as planned, a degree helps to pursuit further studies.
